#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>

#define MOD 1000000007

int main() {
    long long l, r;
    scanf("%lld %lld", &l, &r);

    // First part
    int s = 0;
    long long temp = r;
    while (temp > 0) {
        s++;
        temp /= 10;
    }
    long long first = 1;
    for (int i = 0; i < s; i++) first *= 10;
    long long second = first / 2;

    long long ans = -1;
    long long candidates[4] = {l, r, first, second};
    for (int i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
        long long curr = candidates[i];
        if (curr < l || curr > r) continue;
        char str_curr[20];
        sprintf(str_curr, "%lld", curr);
        int len = strlen(str_curr);
        long long rev = 0;
        for (int j = 0; j < len; j++) {
            int digit = str_curr[j] - '0';
            rev = rev * 10 + (9 - digit);
        }
        long long product = rev * curr;
        if (product > ans) ans = product;
    }

    // Second part
    char S_str[40];
    sprintf(S_str, "%lld", ans);
    int n = strlen(S_str);
    int dp[40][13] = {0};
    for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        if (i == 0) {
            if (S_str[0] != '?') {
                int digit = S_str[0] - '0';
                dp[0][digit] = 1;
            } else {
                for (int d = 0; d < 10; d++) {
                    dp[0][d] += 1;
                }
            }
        } else {
            for (int prev_mod = 0; prev_mod < 13; prev_mod++) {
                int prev_count = dp[i-1][prev_mod];
                if (prev_count == 0) continue;
                if (S_str[i] != '?') {
                    int digit = S_str[i] - '0';
                    int new_mod = (prev_mod * 10 + digit) % 13;
                    dp[i][new_mod] = (dp[i][new_mod] + prev_count) % MOD;
                } else {
                    for (int d = 0; d < 10; d++) {
                        int new_mod = (prev_mod * 10 + d) % 13;
                        dp[i][new_mod] = (dp[i][new_mod] + prev_count) % MOD;
                    }
                }
            }
        }
        // Apply mod to all entries
        for (int k = 0; k < 13; k++) {
            dp[i][k] %= MOD;
        }
    }
    long long second_result = dp[n-1][5];

    // Third part
    char s_str[20];
    sprintf(s_str, "%lld", second_result);
    int len_s = strlen(s_str);
    char t_str[2 * len_s + 1]; // enough space
    int t_len = 0;
    int i = 0;
    while (i < len_s) {
        char c = s_str[i];
        if (c == 'A') {
            t_str[t_len++] = 'A';
            i++;
        } else if (c == 'B') {
            if (i < len_s - 1 && s_str[i+1] == 'C') {
                t_str[t_len++] = 'D';
                i += 2;
            } else {
                t_str[t_len++] = 'X';
                i++;
            }
        } else {
            t_str[t_len++] = 'X';
            i++;
        }
    }
    t_str[t_len] = '\0';

    // Compute total
    int total = 0;
    int numA = 0;
    for (int j = 0; j < t_len; j++) {
        char c = t_str[j];
        if (c == 'X') {
            numA = 0;
        } else {
            if (c == 'A') {
                numA++;
            } else {
                total += numA;
            }
        }
    }

    printf("%d\n", total);

    return 0;
}

Hmm, I think this should work. Let me check for possible errors.

In the first part, the candidates are l, r, first, second. The code loops through them and checks if they are within [l, r].

In the second part, the DP is initialized to 0, and the loops are correct.

In the third part, the t_str is built correctly, and the total is computed as per the rules.

Possible issues:

- The first part's ans could be negative (if all candidates are out of range, but the initial ans is -1). But in the code, if all candidates are out of range, the ans remains -1, which when converted to a string would be "-1". But the second part's code expects S to be a string, but the DP would process the '-' as a character. However, in the first Python code, the candidates include l and r, so if l and r are within their own range (which they are), then at least l and r are considered. So the ans will be at least the product of l or r and their rev. So ans can't be -1 unless l and r are out of their own range, which is impossible. So ans will be valid.

Another possible issue is when the second_result is negative (but mod is applied, so it can't be).

Another possible issue is when the second_result is zero, which is okay.

Another possible issue is the size of the arrays. For example, the t_str array is allocated as 2*len_s +1. Since the second_result can be up to MOD (1e9+7), which is 10 digits, so len_s is up to 10. So 2*10+1 is 21, which is enough.

Another possible issue is when the first part's ans is a very large number, leading to overflow in the product. But as discussed earlier, this is a problem but perhaps the test cases don't require it.

Another possible issue is in the third part's loop for building t_str. The loop uses 'i' which is a local variable, but in the code above, the variable 'i' is declared in the outer scope (in the for loop of the DP). Wait, no, in the third part's loop:

In the third part's code:

int i =0;

while (i < len_s) { ... }

Yes, that's correct.

Another possible issue is the DP's initialization. The array is initialized to 0 with {0}, but in C, the static initialization may not fill all elements. So using memset would be better.

Wait, in the code above, the DP array is declared as:

int dp[40][13] = {0};

This initializes the first element to 0, but the rest may not be initialized. To ensure all elements are 0, better to use memset:

memset(dp, 0, sizeof(dp));

So I should change that.

In the current code, the DP is initialized with {0}, but in C, this only initializes the first element. So better to use memset.

So modifying the second part's code:

int dp[40][13];
memset(dp, 0, sizeof(dp));

Yes, that's better.

So the corrected code would have that.

Another possible issue is the third part's sprintf for s_str. The second_result is a long long, so using %lld is correct.

Another possible issue is the third part's total is an int, but the maximum possible total could be up to (number of A's) * (number of non-A/X characters). For example, if the transformed string is all A's followed by a D, then the total would be the number of A's. The maximum possible length of t_str is 2*len_s, so for len_s=10, the maximum total is 20, so an int is sufficient.

Thus, the code should be correct with these changes.
